Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Within-host seasonal drivers of pathogen dynamics in a fruit bat reservoir
Award.AbstractNarration:
Diseases often follow regular patterns: there is commonly a flu season, for example, and regular cycles in the occurrence of measles and chicken pox are well known. Explanations usually involve patterns of host (human) movement and contact. This project will examine how other factors such as seasonal changes in host status (nutritional or reproductive status, for example) influence the spread of disease. The research focuses on bats, which are known or suspected hosts and reservoirs for a number of diseases. Understanding more about host tolerance to disease will be critical to predicting and preventing new infectious diseases. Results will improve understanding of disease risk and spread, with direct consequences for human health. The researchers will continue to work with scientists in Madagascar, contributing to human and wildlife health and conservation in that country. The award will advance the education and training of a doctoral student, supporting her to develop a new measure of host condition and improved models for disease dynamics. The doctoral student will develop a course in modeling disease dynamics and will continue to engage undergraduate students in the research.

The researchers hypothesize that seasonal fluctuations in adipose tissue underlie a host's strategy of pathogen tolerance versus resistance for a diverse suite of viral, bacterial, and protozoan infections. Adipose tissues may mediate pathogen-induced intracellular damage and promote repair by regulating processes of intracellular autophagy. This regulation would promote host tolerance to infection. During resource-scarce winters, reductions in adiposity could lead to declining function in autophagic processes, allowing for accumulation of intracellular pathogen-induced damage that necessitates immune resistance. The researchers will test these hypotheses using serum samples collected during an 18-month field study of pathogen dynamics in three endemic fruit bats in Madagascar. They will conduct enzyme-immunoassays for leptin, a neuroendocrine signaling hormone secreted by adipose tissue, in serum samples of each individual bat in the dataset to quantify adiposity. Data on adiposity will be used to parameterize a new, within-host model exploring adipose tissue contributions to pathogen damage control. Although seasonal contact patterns often capture epidemic dynamics in human infections, they are insufficient to explain pathogen persistence, and the observed seasonality of disease transmission, in a number of important wildlife hosts, including bats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant was awarded to our project entitled, “Within-host seasonal drivers of pathogen dynamics in a fruit bat reservoir.” Old World Fruit Bats have received increasing attention in recent years for their role as the purported reservoir hosts for several highly virulent, emerging zoonotic diseases, including rabies and related lyssaviruses, Hendra and Nipah henipaviruses, Ebola and Marburg filoviruses, and SARS and MERS coronaviruses. In many parts of the world (including Madagascar, where this NSF-DDIG research was carried out), Old World Fruit Bats are consumed by humans as bushmeat, thus heightening opportunities for cross-species transmission of bat viruses to human hosts. Intriguingly, most documented spillover events of bat-borne viruses have occurred at the end of the dry season, concomitant with the synchronous reproductive season for the fruit bat system in question. Researchers debate the mechanisms underpinning such seasonality, and currently available data are insufficient to distinguish among several potential hypotheses, including theories describing (a) perfectly immunizing infections by which transmission is maintained via an annual influx of naïve juveniles, (b) immunizing infections with waning annual immunity, and (c) persistent infections with periodic shedding events. In this project, the authors sought to (1) characterize the diversity of potentially zoonotic viruses infecting wild fruit bats in Madagascar, (2) document any signature of seasonality in the transmission dynamics supporting these viruses across an 18-month time series, and (3) fit a series of compartmental models to age-seroprevalence data for these bat viruses in attempt to decipher the relative contributions of population-level and within-host drivers of pathogen dynamics. The authors effectively met all three of their research aims. They (1) collected, assayed, and analyzed serum samples from Malagasy fruit bats seropositive to Nipah-related henipaviruses and Ebola-related filoviruses, (2) demonstrated evidence of elevated antibody titers during the seasonal gestation period for female bats and the fruit abundant wet season for male bats, and (3) fit models describing potential mechanistic hypotheses for this seasonality to age-seroprevalence data. The authors found that a model constructed around assumptions of persistent infection with periodic viral shedding fit the data the best. These findings offer important insights into our understanding of the within-host dynamics underpinning transmission of bat-borne viruses, thus greatly enhancing our capacity for zoonotic prediction and corresponding public heath intervention. Additionally, this project supported the dissertation research of one US and one Malagasy PhD student and resulted in the inauguration of an annual workshop in quantitative epidemiology for Malagasy students, led by the project PIs.
